ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I came into this class looking to embrace more of my Chinese identity, and I definitely think that objective was achieved. I feel a lot more comfortable talking with my Chinese international peers and engaging with the Chinese language in general. I learned a lot of new vocabulary that has actually increased my ability to express myself in Chinese and thus, to my parents, which I struggled with before.
Improved by Chinese writing and speaking! Each lesson was very relevant, and learned many new Chinese characters.
I was able to develop a much greater understanding of my cultural heritage and attain a better grasp of the Chinese language.
I learned Chinese in a colloquies setting. I came in knowing around 400 characters and coming out I now know more than 1500.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Pros:
I liked how we tended to have a lot more interactive discussions than just lecture. This meant that I never really fell asleep in class. I also liked how the structure of the lecture slides and the project/essay topics we were assigned. A lot of our big assignments were super fun to complete, as it gave us a lot of freedom in terms of our response. I was able to talk about subjects that I actually found an interest in.

Cons:
I'd say most of the vocabulary we learned was pretty relevant and could appear in the day-to-day life, but there were also some words that seemed slightly outdated or too formal. There was also the issue of our "textbook", which was really just an unpublished PDF apparently written by someone in the Chinese department at Yale. Therefore, some of the subtopics did not seem very refined and relevant, and there were many typos in the textbooks, ranging from simple grammatical errors to the complete omission or incorrect placement of certain content.
Very engaging and fun class! Students knew each other very well.

Strengths: everyone gets really close in class because it's such a small seminar class
Weaknesses: as a result, we often get distracted with personal details about our lives instead of finishing the curriculum

strengths: organized, fair
weaknesses: so much unexpected work towards the end

Strengths: small group, good atmosphere
Weaknesses: doesn't facilitate enough actual discussion, could be more emphasis/curriculum on chinese traditions/idioms/etc.
Our instructor was excellent, and the course was well structured with clear guidelines on how to do well in the class.
I thought the course was very well designed, fun, and interactive.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would. The class was a small and interactive class, which I really enjoyed. The professor is also really nice and easy to communicate with, both in person and over email.
only if you are a heritage student and your Chinese is genuinely AP-level
Yes. Each lesson was prepared thoughtfully to facilitate student learning, and there was enough creative freedom given for individual and group projects.
Yes, I think the course is relatively straight-forward and if one puts in the time to study and prepare, they will do well in the course.
I would. You learn so much in this course and its very fun and interactive. I would take the course again if I could!
